Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.

Instructor: Thomas Alan Kwan  Thomas did an excellent job. I really appreciated his passion for the class and then enthusiasm he brought to the experience. 10/10
Instructor: Thomas Alan Kwan  It was clear how much Thomas cared about making our class experience a good one. He was always responsive, available and enthusiastic.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Mark Falinski  Very helpful with practical feedback.

Instructor: Thomas Alan Kwan  Really enjoyed having Thomas as a TA for this course. He was very knowledgable and supportive of the students and their projects. Also has a very interesting, soothing voice...a plus!
Instructor: Thomas Alan Kwan  Very responsive and helpful.
Instructor: Thomas Alan Kwan  Thomas gave great feedback on our design process and was generally very supportive/encouraging.
Instructor: Thomas Alan Kwan  I felt the other teaching fellows could have been given more opportunities to interact with students.
Instructor: Thomas Alan Kwan  N/A
Instructor: Thomas Alan Kwan  He is great.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Although I know it is a separate class, I would have liked to have more background on concepts in engineering and green chemistry.

The course title should be "sustainable innovation" or "sustainable design" as there is nothing of engineering in the class unfortunately. Assignments or class projects should be more relevant to industry/real world... rather than kindergartens (e.g. the marshmallow challenge) First homework grading was based on words count rather than actual answers ...

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Enjoyed the resources available in the CEID space and the introduction to design thinking.

This course was hands-on and thoroughly engaging. I've spent a lot of my career talking about engineering and sustainability, and in this course I actually got to do it. They teach a valuable skill set.
Encouragement of creativity and a lot of support available.
Getting familiar with CEID space.
Working in CEID, making prototypes
Very informal and creative. Really teaches students how to think critically and creatively.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Wish there was a much deeper analysis of sustainable design and green engineering - this would include case studies or other examples. Activities that were somehow structured around this would be more beneficial than activities such as the marshmallow challenge or the lego man challenge that had nothing to do with sustainable design or green engineering.
I would have wanted more time to spend on the final design project. We would have benefited from more time for iteration and developing our initial idea.
I think it would have been nice to have more time to work on the final project or at least have known about it for more time.
Teaching of GE and SD, and how students implement those idea in projects. Interesting group projects would certainly help.
More resources or extra sessions to delve deeper into ideation strategies or how to deal with difficult group dynamics.
Too much focus on innovation at the expense of practicality. Not enough support for team dynamics that were impeding projects and learning.
More focus on engineering and material science

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: No. Very little connection between lectures and how to take action to create sustainable designs.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course gave me engineering experience that I really wanted.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted a class that pushed me out of my comfort zone and allowed me to develop my ideas in a maker space.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Not entirely. I really wanted to learn more about how green engineering is realized in industry but this was only touched upon superficially.
Yes!
No. Very little GE and SD was taught. Simply read the 12 Principles of GE that the professors wrote. No teaching of implementation, trade-offs.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: As with any group project, there were varying levels of commitment to the work. I think that more emphasis on the subject matter rather than interpersonal dynamics in this class would have been more beneficial.
Group work was so important. I learned a lot about how to work well and not well in a group. You need to learn to leverage your group to generate better ideas than any one person could.

It was focused a lot on group work and I learned this was a very important part of the success of a project. I enjoyed working with diverse groups. I struggled during the final project lacking an engineer and only having 3 of us. It's clear how important it is to have diverse members.
Some groups were great. Finding a time to meet with some students was very tough. Better to set up a "lab time" in the syllabus so students can block the time from the beginning of the semester.

The workload is too great to do independently, which makes group work necessary. But sometimes the team dynamics impeded projects. Some students obviously pick up on the creative process faster than others, and randomly joining students together makes it difficult to function on the higher level that's necessary.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Interesting course.
Be prepared to invest a lot of time toward the end of the semester.

You won't actually learn any green engineering or sustainable design. Very broad overview of LCA, cradle-to-cradle design, but not actually how to implement it. There was a single class about different material types in the second half of the semester, not even taught by the professors and only occurred because the students requested it. Grading of group projects are much more aesthetic rather than functional. Final projects challengers were very weak. Professors give you a hard time for not laughing at their jokes and then get told you're not enthusiastic. When students gave feedback that it was odd that we had to print out assignments in order to hand them in, we were also given a hard time. No individual projects is a missed opportunity for students to take large risks. Wildly inconsistent grading makes it hard to care about any assignment. Working with classmates make or break this class since lectures are pretty worthless, so take it with friends.
Be prepared to dedicate significant time to the course. Make sure you fill out the surveys to get matched with a good partner.
A great course, but way too much workload to take in the second semester of your senior year. Other course loads will suffer.
